emailColumn.title: 24ttl

authorInfo.title: From the Author
authorInfo.description:
24TTL.net is a company that specializes in providing innovative solutions for e-commerce, focusing on enhancing the online shopping experience for both retailers and brands. The company is headquartered in Dubai, United Arab Emirates, but operates internationally, including recently expanding to Seoul, South Korea, to tap into the innovative e-commerce market there.

 24TTL is recognized for changing the customer experience in e-commerce and is trusted by Fortune Global 500 companies. They have partnerships with over 400 retailers and marketplaces, focusing on delivering a seamless and omnichannel buying process for online shoppers.

materialsUsed: UAE Ministry of Economy. (2025). Business Expansion in UAE: Opportunities & Growth Strategies.
Netherlands Trade & Investment Office. (2024). Market Entry Strategy Guide for the Netherlands.
Indonesia Investment Coordinating Board (BKPM). (2025). Business Expansion to Indonesia: Complete Strategy Guide.
Mexico Trade & Investment Promotion. (2024). Benefits and Challenges of Expanding to Mexico.
Harvard Business Review. (2023). Cultural Understanding Impact on Global Expansion Strategies.
McKinsey & Company. (2024). International Business Expansion: Cultural Adaptation Framework.
World Bank. (2025). Doing Business Report - Cross-Country Analysis.
Baker Institute. (2024). Nearshoring in Mexico: Opportunities and Challenges.

keyTakeaways.title: Key Takeaways
keyTakeaways.description: Successful international expansion requires local entity establishment, deep cultural understanding, systematic business development approach, and long-term commitment. Quick spray-and-pray strategies often fail - sustainable growth comes from building reputation, trust, and genuine local partnerships over time.

emails.subject: The Genesis: From Russia to Dubai - Our First International Leap
emails.body:
**Our international expansion journey began in 2016 ğŸ“…, not through careful market analysis, but through client relationships.** We were already established as an agency in ğŸ‡·ğŸ‡º Russia, working with big businesses and positioning ourselves as 'product and services' - offering **e-commerce design services plus automation scripts** ğŸ–¥ï¸.

**The pivotal moment came when our key client, LG, relocated their manager to ğŸ‡¦ğŸ‡ª Dubai.** They recommended us saying: 'You've been serving us in ğŸ‡·ğŸ‡º Russia for five ğŸ“… years, and your work is significantly better than what's available locally in ğŸ‡¦ğŸ‡ª Dubai. Let's give it a shot.' **This client relationship became our gateway into the MENA region** ğŸš€.

**From 2016 through 2017 ğŸ“…, we operated in 'business trip mode'** - fly in âœˆï¸, meet clients, get briefs, deliver services. It was essentially the same work we did in ğŸ‡·ğŸ‡º Russia: **content management, design, and ğŸŒ website support for LG.com**, just for the ğŸ‡¦ğŸ‡ª Dubai region. **The ğŸ‡¦ğŸ‡ª UAE market was far behind ğŸ‡·ğŸ‡º Russia in e-commerce maturity**, so we didn't rush into major investments ğŸ’°.

**This experience taught us that operating internationally requires local presence.** While we could serve existing clients remotely, real ğŸ“ˆ growth only came later when we established local ğŸ‘¨â€ğŸ’¼ğŸ‘©â€ğŸ’¼ teams and full business development operations.

highlight.title: Client-Driven Market Entry
highlight.description: Sometimes the best market opportunities come through existing client relationships rather than theoretical market analysis - but success requires eventual local establishment

emails.subject: Why Local Entities Matter: From Services to SaaS Across Markets
emails.body:
**When we pivoted from agency services to IT/SaaS business post-2019 ğŸ“…, everything changed.** The IT foundation enabled scaling - **you can sell the same product multiple â° times across different ğŸª markets**, and **it can even work remotely** ğŸŒ. This realization drove our ğŸ‡ªğŸ‡º European expansion plans ğŸš€.

**We established entities in ğŸ‡³ğŸ‡± Netherlands (2020 ğŸ“…) and later ğŸ‡¦ğŸ‡ª Dubai (2022 ğŸ“…).** The lesson became clear: **big clients prefer local ğŸ¤ partners** due to taxes, VAT reclaim, and regulatory compliance. **Cross-country invoicing is messy** ğŸ˜… - you need local presence for enterprise clients.

**We launched 10 products; only 4 survived.** But those survivors could scale internationally ğŸš€. In ğŸ‡³ğŸ‡± Netherlands, we leveraged our ğŸ¤ partnership with [Hatch](https://www.hatch.co) (later acquired by ğŸ‡ºğŸ‡¸ American company [PricePider](https://www.pricepider.com)). **ğŸ‡ªğŸ‡º Europe offered higher purchasing power, average order values, and GMV** ğŸ’° - but it was also conservative and competitive âš”ï¸.

**Post-2022 ğŸ“… invasion, ğŸ‡ºğŸ‡¸ Americans said 'We don't work with ğŸ‡·ğŸ‡º Russians' and canceled our contract.** We had to pivot fast âš¡. **ğŸ‡¦ğŸ‡ª Dubai seemed neutral** - only 1-ğŸ• hour â° time difference from ğŸ‡·ğŸ‡º Russia, open bank accounts, existing infrastructure. This forced move actually opened new opportunities we hadn't considered ğŸ‰.

highlight.title: Local Entity Imperative
highlight.description: Enterprise clients require local legal entities for tax efficiency and regulatory compliance - remote operations have fundamental limitations for B2B growth

emails.subject: Market Selection: Why UAE, Mexico, and Indonesia Made Sense
emails.body:
**Post-invasion, we considered multiple ğŸª markets: ğŸ‡ºğŸ‡¸ U.S., Portugal, Asia, LatAm.** We decided to split efforts across **ğŸ‡²ğŸ‡½ Mexico, ğŸ‡®ğŸ‡© Indonesia, and ğŸ‡¦ğŸ‡ª UAE** to see where traction happened ğŸ¯.

**ğŸ‡²ğŸ‡½ Mexico was chosen as Spanish-speaking LATAM gateway** - my sister Anna co-ran accelerator Hacker Sprint in Chile/ğŸ‡²ğŸ‡½ Mexico/Brazil and praised ğŸ‡²ğŸ‡½ Mexico's business climate. I thought it'd be a **ğŸ‡ºğŸ‡¸ U.S. proxy** - I was âŒ wrong. **Cultural friction with 'maÃ±ana' attitude hurt operations** ğŸ˜…. Cost: ~ğŸ’° $130K, yielded one client.

**ğŸ‡®ğŸ‡© Indonesia happened because our ğŸ‡¦ğŸ‡ª Dubai client moved there.** With **270M people and fast-growing e-commerce** ğŸ“ˆ, it offered huge potential with low âš”ï¸ competition. We now have 6 clients ([Samsung](https://www.samsung.com), [Panasonic](https://www.panasonic.com)) but smaller contract values ğŸ’µ. **We're expanding from ğŸ‡®ğŸ‡© Indonesia to Singapore/Malaysia** ğŸš€.

**ğŸ‡¦ğŸ‡ª UAE remained steady since 2016 ğŸ“….** Almost no âš”ï¸ competitors in ğŸ‡¦ğŸ‡ª Dubai compared to ğŸ‡ªğŸ‡º Europe. **ğŸ‡³ğŸ‡± Netherlands was tied to our Hatch ğŸ¤ partnership** - logical ğŸ‡ªğŸ‡º European base with high e-commerce maturity. But post-acquisition, we pivoted fully to ğŸ‡¦ğŸ‡ª UAE by mid-2022 ğŸ“….

**Each ğŸª market taught us different lessons about âš”ï¸ competition, culture, and customer behavior** ğŸ“.

highlight.title: Portfolio Approach to Markets
highlight.description: Testing multiple markets simultaneously helps identify where natural traction occurs - but requires significant resources and cultural adaptation for each region

emails.subject: Expensive Lessons: What We Got Wrong in the U.S. Market
emails.body:
**We didn't set budgets or deadlines - decisions were intuitive** ğŸ¤”. We'd wait for crisis or clear signals to stop. **This lack of systematic approach cost us dearly in the ğŸ‡ºğŸ‡¸ U.S.** ğŸ’°âŒ

**Our biggest ğŸ‡ºğŸ‡¸ U.S. âŒ mistake: thinking 1-2 person ğŸ‘¨â€ğŸ’¼ğŸ‘©â€ğŸ’¼ teams could work for enterprise ğŸ’µ sales.** **Breaking into Samsung or LG requires systemic effort** ğŸ¯ - not something a small ğŸ‘¨â€ğŸ’¼ğŸ‘©â€ğŸ’¼ team can accomplish. **The ğŸ‡ºğŸ‡¸ U.S. is hyper-competitive** âš”ï¸ (Salesforce, SAP dominate), and **big brands are nearly impossible to crack without something extraordinary** âœ¨.

**We can't target SMBs because our tools solve pain points for big brands** managing multichannel inventory (Amazon, eBay, etc.). **SMBs can hire two people to handle this - they don't need our solution** ğŸ¤·â€â™‚ï¸.

**ğŸ‡ºğŸ‡¸ U.S. costs: ğŸ’° $50K-$100K** - salaries, travel, exhibits. In 2019 ğŸ“…, I opened Delaware entity, did roadshow, attended [NRF](https://nrf.com) Chicago, hired small biz-dev ğŸ‘¨â€ğŸ’¼ğŸ‘©â€ğŸ’¼ team. **After a ğŸ“… year of significant spend ğŸ’°, it went nowhere** âŒ.

**The lesson: enterprise ğŸ’µ sales require extraordinary value propositions and systematic, well-funded approaches** ğŸ’¡. You can't casually enter the world's most competitive âš”ï¸ ğŸª market.

highlight.title: Enterprise Sales Reality Check
highlight.description: Hyper-competitive markets like the U.S. require extraordinary value propositions and systematic approaches - small teams cannot penetrate established enterprise markets

emails.subject: Cultural Nuances: The Hidden Business Killers We Discovered
emails.body:
**Going international means working with different nationalities - cultural nuances can make or break your business** ğŸŒ. We learned this the hard way across multiple ğŸª markets.

**In ğŸ‡²ğŸ‡½ Mexico and ğŸ‡®ğŸ‡© Indonesia, basic feedback like 'You're great guys' means nothing.** **We took politeness as validation** - huge âŒ mistake. **ğŸ‡²ğŸ‡½ Mexicans literally can't say 'no' directly** ğŸš«. There's even YouTube videos on how to say 'yes' properly - if you say 'sim', they instantly know you're foreign ğŸ¤¦â€â™‚ï¸.

**We thought three ğŸª markets would behave like ğŸ‡·ğŸ‡º Russian ones.** **We mapped it out mathematically: ğŸ’° 300k MRR Ã— 20 ğŸª markets = unicorn!** ğŸ¦„ But **it doesn't work like that without deep integration** - being seen 20+ â° times at events, knowing everyone, actually living there ğŸ .

**Hiring costs varied dramatically:** ğŸ‡²ğŸ‡½ Mexico ğŸ’° $4k/month for English speakers, ğŸ‡®ğŸ‡© Indonesia ğŸ’° $1k, ğŸ‡¦ğŸ‡ª Dubai ğŸ’° $2.5k-$3k. **ğŸ‡²ğŸ‡½ Mexican ğŸ‘¨â€ğŸ’¼ğŸ‘©â€ğŸ’¼ team was toughest - no feedback tolerance, 'ğŸ‡·ğŸ‡º Russian bluntness' backfired** ğŸ˜…. We saw people playing ğŸ“± phone games in Zoom booths.

**ğŸ‡®ğŸ‡© Indonesian ğŸ‘¨â€ğŸ’¼ğŸ‘©â€ğŸ’¼ team: chill but responsible** ğŸ˜Œ. Cultural fit matters enormously for ğŸ‘¨â€ğŸ’¼ğŸ‘©â€ğŸ’¼ team performance and retention.

highlight.title: Cultural Misreading Trap
highlight.description: Politeness is often mistaken for business validation - understanding indirect communication styles and cultural feedback patterns is crucial for accurate market assessment

emails.subject: Fracturing Success: How We Split Teams Across Four Markets
emails.body:
**We had to split the ğŸ‘¨â€ğŸ’¼ğŸ‘©â€ğŸ’¼ team, mostly by dialogue and logic.** **We fractured into 4 businesses: mature ğŸ‡·ğŸ‡º Russia + 3 chaotic startups** ğŸš€. Now it's consolidated as 'ğŸ‡·ğŸ‡º Russia + global startup.'

**Business development splits into three functions:** 1) **Contact miners** ([LinkedIn](https://linkedin.com) scraping), 2) **SDRs** (ğŸ“§ emails/ğŸ’¬ WhatsApp), 3) **Account executives** (closing ğŸ¤). **We tried doing it ourselves, but broken English and local distrust killed us** âŒ.

**ğŸ‘¨â€ğŸ’¼ğŸ‘©â€ğŸ’¼ Team allocation by culture fit:** Gen went to ğŸ‡²ğŸ‡½ Mexico - he's into football âš½, the culture. **ğŸ‡²ğŸ‡½ Mexico fit his personality** âœ…. Tyoma went to ğŸ‡®ğŸ‡© Indonesia - **Bali lifestyle vibed with him** ğŸï¸. Cultural alignment matters for leadership effectiveness ğŸ’¡.

**In ğŸ‡¦ğŸ‡ª Dubai, we hired Syrians, Iranians, Indians** - multicultural ğŸ‘¨â€ğŸ’¼ğŸ‘©â€ğŸ’¼ team with regional expertise ğŸŒ. **Language is everything** ğŸ—£ï¸ - we learned to hire locals through agencies for authentic ğŸª market penetration.

**Tried lead generation agencies (ğŸ’° $5k/month for ğŸ¤ meetings).** First month: great results âœ…. Then: **ghosted across ğŸ‡ªğŸ‡º Europe, ğŸ‡²ğŸ‡½ Mexico, Brazil** ğŸ‘». **We copied their playbooks** for process rigor, parsing 200 leads â†’ SDR â†’ call scripts â†’ [LinkedIn](https://linkedin.com) automation ğŸ¤–.

highlight.title: Cultural Leadership Matching
highlight.description: Matching leadership personalities with market cultures significantly improves team performance and market penetration - cultural fit affects operational success

emails.subject: Managing Chaos: Lessons from Running Four Markets Simultaneously
emails.body:
**Managing four ğŸª markets at once was quite difficult** ğŸ˜…. Gen complained I ignored ğŸ‡²ğŸ‡½ Mexico (**timezone hell** ğŸ•). ğŸ‡®ğŸ‡© Indonesia was easier (+4ğŸ• h). **We had syncs at weird ğŸ• hours** trying to coordinate everything â°.

**We had a 'Growth Director' overseeing expansion - big âŒ mistake: too early to delegate.** ğŸ“… Year one, I was barely involved in biz-dev ops. **Reports sounded rosy ('ğŸ¤ Meetings! Connections!'), but no ğŸ’µ revenue.** After 1.5 ğŸ“… years, we pivoted hard: slashed ğŸ‘¨â€ğŸ’¼ğŸ‘©â€ğŸ’¼ teams, hyper-focused on deals ğŸ¯.

**Our biggest âŒ mistakes:**
1) **Spray-and-pray approach cost ğŸ’° $2M** but taught us fast ğŸ“
2) **Should've validated first, scaled later** - now we test ğŸ‡°ğŸ‡· Korea with 1 FT + 2 interns ğŸ‘¨â€ğŸ“ğŸ‘©â€ğŸ“
3) **Timezone sprawl hurts coordination** ğŸ•ğŸ˜µ

**Surprising âœ… win: community-building** ğŸ˜ï¸. Only Tyoma and I believed in it. **ğŸ‡·ğŸ‡º Russia flopped; ğŸ‡®ğŸ‡© Indonesia exploded** ğŸ’¥. Now it's our #1 B2B lever ğŸš€. **Meta-events (IDRF forum) - we underestimated their power** âš¡.

**Current priorities:** ğŸ‡¦ğŸ‡ª Dubai #1 (daily presence ğŸ“), ğŸ‡®ğŸ‡© Indonesia #2 (timezone advantage ğŸ•), ğŸ‡·ğŸ‡º Russia (steady ops âš™ï¸), ğŸ‡²ğŸ‡½ Mexico ('neglected child' ğŸ‘¶).

highlight.title: Reputation Before Revenue
highlight.description: Community-building and reputation development often matter more than direct sales efforts - B2B markets require trust and relationship-building over time
